awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Cross-Validation of Empirical and Physics-based ground motion predictions
awd_abstract_narration:
Many densely populated areas such as Tokyo, Seattle, and Los Angeles are located near active plate boundaries capable of producing large earthquakes. These cities are often built on top of sedimentary basins which trap, focus and amplify earthquake seismic energy. Prediction of strong ground motions is critical in these areas to prevent the loss of life and property in future large events. Here, the principal investigators pioneered a new empirical approach which uses seismic ambient noise, for example generated by ocean waves, to predict large earthquake ground motions. They are also expert in 3D numerical simulations of ground-notion dynamics. The team join effort to cross-validate these approaches in the greater Los Angeles. They use ambient noise and small past-earthquake data to create a suite of large scenario earthquakes (magnitude 6.5 to 7.8) on the southern San Andreas fault. The simulations allow evaluating whether the underlying geological structure may channel earthquake waves and thereby strongly amplify the ground motions. This 2-year project will help mitigating seismic hazards in southern California. The developped methodology can be applied to other urban areas located in similar geological context. The project also supports an early career female scientist and provides training to three graduate students.

The goal of the project is to characterize the coupling effect between the amplification due to seismic waveguides and that due to source directivity. This effect may enhance shaking intensity in sedimentary basins. The project uses southern California as a natural laboratory. Other large metropolitan areas, such as Tokyo, Mexico City, Seattle, Salt Lake City and Jakarta, are subjected to similar hazards. Here, the team innovates in using cross-validation between two state-of-the-art ground-motion prediction approaches: the ambient-noise Virtual Earthquake Approach and 3D dynamic simulations. This cross-validation allows i) establishing bounds of confidence in the two methods, ii) examining the coupling between path and source effects in enhancing ground motion, and iii) evaluating the extent of nonlinear effects on future ground motions. The novelty of the project is the unique combination of theoretical and observational seismology. In this effort, newly collected data from dense arrays including both broadband and nodal-seismic instruments will be exploited.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Sedimentary basins are places where humans live because of natural resources. They are also sensitive to earthquake ground motions due to seismic amplification in the soft sediments. Understanding and modeling the effects of seismic amplification is critical for urban environments close to plate boundaries. The greater Los Angeles area is such a place: it hosts millions of people and sits near the San Andreas Fault. Previous wavefield simulations have suggested that seismic waves amplify between the San Andreas and Los Angeles. This project focused on verifying this using empirical approaches, collaborating with San Diego State University, and generating 3D wave propagation synthetic seismograms. The project leverages dense nodal deployments that were asynchronously deployed in the San Bernardino, the Chino, and the San Gabriel Basins.

 

The project's intellectual merit was centered around massive data processing, analysis of the cross-correlation of seismic data, and comparison with state-of-the-art simulated wavefield. The seismic networks were deployed over different times over three years, and our team attempted to provide an overall view of the information buried in the collection of seismic arrays. Our project aimed to compare these time series with synthetics calculated in a 3D velocity model. The comparison demonstrated commonalities in the types of seismic waves that dominate the ground motion in sedimentary basins, mostly Rayleigh waves and some Love waves, and highlighted differences in spatial pattern. Both simulations and empirical estimates predicted complex patterns in seismic amplification, demonstrating that wave propagation paths, including basin edge effects, are critical to understanding and cannot be over-simplified with a simplified parameterization of sediment thickness. We predicted robust amplification in the San Bernardino Basin, on the edges of the Chino basins, and funneling of seismic waves into the Los Angeles Basin from a northern passageway (the San Gabriel Basin) and a southern passageway (through Chino). We also learned that asynchronous deployments, which entail capturing a diverse ambient seismic field, presented challenges in interpreting seismic amplitudes. An additional intellectual contribution was the development of cloud-native workflows and containerized software to process large amounts (100TB) of seismic data on Amazon Web Services in the computing language Julia.

 

The project's broader impact entailed training a group of students and postdocs. The Harvard/UW team trained three undergraduate students, one of which led the analysis. The partially supported postdoc mentored and collaborated with the SDSU graduate and undergraduate students and contributed to intellectual discussions and software. The team was entirely remote, developing cloud-native tools and delivering the project results in person and remotely at multiple conferences. The scientific impact addresses essential societal issues as it demonstrates complex, strong ground motion patterns that may affect the population in the greater Los Angeles area but that are also relevant to many other urban basins at seismic risk (Seattle, San Francisco, Tokyo, Mexico City, Bogota, …).

 

REFERENCES:

Denolle, M., J. Schmitt, L. Ermert, T. Clements, N. Wang, and K. Olsen (2020), "Illuminating seismic waveguides using noise cross correlations and numerical simulations", S005-03, presented at 2020 AGU Fall Meeting, 1-17 December 2020.

 

Schmitt, J., T. Clements, L. Retailleau, A. Mordret, G. Beroza, and M. Denolle (2020), "Comprehensive California-wide large-scale noise cross correlations", S022-08, presented at 2020 AGU Fall Meeting, 1-17 December 2020.

 

Schmitt, J., T. Clements, N. Wang, K. Okubo, K. Olsen, and M. Denolle (2020), "Ground motion prediction using ambient seismic noise on a large-N array in the LA basin" Poster #212, presented at 2020 SCEC Annual Meeting, 16 September  2020.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/12/2023
Modified by: Marine A Denolle
